Why are the life spans, etc., of the great brahma heaven and the heaven of non-perceptual beings not distinguished and not established separately? In the formless realm, there is no location at all, because formless dharmas, past and future, and non-indicative form all have no location. This is definitely so according to principle.
However, there are four kinds of superior and inferior distinctions in the form of karmic maturation.

The first is the sphere of infinite space, the second is the sphere of infinite consciousness, the third is the sphere of nothingness, and the fourth is the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception.
These four kinds are called the formless realm. They are distinguished by the superiority and inferiority of birth, not by location.
Because those who attain concentration in this place, when their life ends, are born in this very place.
And when they die and are reborn in the desire or form realms, the intermediate existence arises in this very place.

Because they gradually detach from desire and gradually attain that concentration, and because birth is inferior or superior, the order is like this. Because the power of the cause of birth is small or great, the result is also small or great.
What do sentient beings born in the formless realm take as their support for the continuity of mind and so forth?
What is the reason for suddenly giving rise to doubt again?
Because there is absolutely no self among all dharmas.
The mind and mental factors in the desire and form realms can continue and evolve by relying on a physical body;
Since there is no material body in the formless realm, mind and so on should not have the meaning of a continuous series.

In order to show that they have a support, it is said that mind and so on continue in a series supported by the similarity of species and the vitality faculty. translated: The four consciousnesses of eye, etc., each have as their support and as their dominant condition the immediately antecedent cessation of mind and their own material organs. The material organs, the body organ, the similarity of species, the vitality faculty, acquisition, etc., and birth, etc., are only dominant conditions, because the body consciousness uses mind and the body organ as its support and dominant condition, but only uses the great elements that are the support of the body organ, the similarity of species, the vitality faculty, acquisition, etc., and birth, etc., as dominant conditions, not as a support.
The sixth consciousness has as its support the immediately past mind, and this mind is its support and dominant condition. The body, faculties, species, life, and so on are only dominant conditions.
Thus the minds of sentient beings in the realm of desire and the realm of form are supported by form, by species, life, and so on, and continue in a series.
Since sentient beings in the formless realm have no form, their minds are supported only by species and life and continue in a series. This does not mean that they have no support.

The difference between a support and a supported dharma is that the supported dharma arises and is manifested only when the support exists and does not when the support does not exist. This is the characteristic of a support.
That which definitely has the characteristic of a support and is subject to change is called a support and has the characteristic of a supported dharma.
Even though these dharmas are the support of mind, etc., sometimes mind, etc., is not manifested because of the obstruction of other dharmas.
When mind, etc., is manifested, it must have a support, and therefore it is said that these dharmas are the support of mind, etc.

We actually see that mind and so on are definitely not born in a dead body, and although they temporarily cease in a living body, they will definitely arise again. Therefore the characteristics of the support of form and so on are well established.

Consequently, we know that form, sound, smell, and so on are not supports for mind and its activities, because in external events there is form, sound, and so on, but mind and its activities never evolve there.
Mind and so on do not definitely evolve in accordance with the immediately antecedent condition of manas. How can you say that manas is their support?
That which evolves in accordance with something is that which is transformed by it. Because manas ceases and mind and so on arise, why is manas not a support?

The same is not true of the mind and so on of the same species and so on, which are supports for mind and so on, as is the case with the immediately antecedent condition of manas. Therefore the characteristics of the support are different from the characteristics of a support.

Thus the minds of sentient beings in the realms of desire and form are born and perish with the four aggregates as their nature as a support, but only the form aggregate is capable of being a support.
Even when the mind is transformed by the disturbance of wine and so on, there is no consciousness that has form as a support.

The consciousness that is supported and produced by the sameness and stability of the transformation of the sense base is not necessarily transformed and produced by the transformation of form, because even when there is no form, mind still exists. It can be the nature of a support, but it does not act as a support.
Therefore, in the desire realm and the form realm, the six consciousnesses are born with the four aggregates as their simultaneous support.
In the formless realm, mental consciousness is born with only the three aggregates as its simultaneous support, because it has no form.
If this is so, why does the Abhidharmasamuccaya-vyÄkhyÄ say that the formless mind, etc., are supported by sameness of species and life?

It is said that they definitely have the same support and are not confused. That is, although mind and its activities are mutual supports, they are not necessarily the same, because they do not support themselves.
Also, they are not confused, because when one is born in a certain stage, the mind and its activities of that stage are born and not those of other stages.
Sameness of species and life are the same support for mind, etc.
Also, when one is born in a certain stage, only the mind, etc., of that stage are born.

On the basis of these two, one generates a mind of a different stage, and on the basis of these two, one generates a mind of oneâ€™s own stage. Only on the basis of these two is one said to be born in a certain stage, because the karmic result that is attracted by action is uninterrupted. Therefore these two are said to be the support that is the same and not confused.
Mind and so on are not like this, and therefore they are not mentioned.

If these two did not exist, when the four aggregates of a different stage were present, then sentient beings would be said to belong to a different stage, and not to this stage, because the karmic result attracted by previous action of this stage would not be continuous.

But this cannot be accepted. Therefore you should understand that just as the homogeneous character and life in the realm of desire and form are the support of mind, etc., even though sometimes a mind of a different stage is generated, the body, etc., in this life will definitely attract the generation of a mind of oneâ€™s own stage.
In the formless realm, even though there is no body, the homogeneous character and life are definitely the support of mind, etc. Therefore the verse speaks of them in a one-sided way.

The homogeneous character and life faculty are the projecting cause, because they are the retribution of action. They are the cause of the continuation of other forms of retribution, like the roots of a tree are the support of the trunk and so on.
We see that the leaves, branches, and trunk of a tree, although born of the same species, exist supported by the roots. Therefore the organs of eye, etc., are not supported only by action.
This also explains the case of birth in the formless realms.
The mind and so on born of action must have a separate cause as support. Therefore the ÅšÄriputrÃ¢bhidharma does not say that the four aggregates are the support of the five organs.

The evolving consciousness uses feeling, etc., as its support. Because of this, the treatise speaks in general of possession, nonpossession, etc., and their sounds, and does not mention their specific names. This is because they are not only born of action, and even if they are born of action, they are not necessarily continuous.
Therefore the treatise speaks in general of consciousness as the support of the aggregates, and does not speak of feeling, etc., as the support of consciousness.
How do these dharmas become the support of mind, etc.?
Because if they are absent, mind, etc., of the same stage will definitely not be born, just as in the case of the body, etc., as their support.
Or, because it is the cause of non-confusion, one who is born in a higher stage does not possess the good of a lower stage.
Also, one does not possess the nature of an ordinary being of a different stage, etc.
Therefore, the principle that it is the support of the nature of existence is completely established.
Other masters say:
Even though there is no wind, etc., a flame does not arise if there is no pit, etc.
If those dharmas do not exist, mind, etc., do not arise. Therefore, we know that mind, etc., use them as supports.
Or, there are disciples who make this inquiry and request: Dissociated dharmas should be like the material body and also be able to act as supports to generate mental consciousness, etc.

When mind comprehensively cognizes the characteristics of an object, only then can feeling, etc., grasp the specific characteristics. Therefore, they follow mind, but mind does not follow them.
However, mind and mental activities are called reciprocally similar and reciprocally supporting because they have the same effect.

Why does the Abhidharmasamuccaya not say that these two are supports for the continuity of mind, etc., in the realm of desire and the realm of form, and only say that they are supported by the material body?

Although homogeneous character, life, etc., in the realm of desire and the realm of form are always continuous and can be supports, the body is gross and obvious and for that reason is mentioned in preference to the others.
Or, in order to establish that homogeneous character and life exist apart from the body, it is said that they are supported by the body.
It is not the case that in the formless realm or other stages, action and the mind, etc., are not always present.
Or, in order to show that homogeneous character, life, etc., also evolve supported by the body, it is said that they are supported by the body.
Although they and the body are mutually supporting, the body is superior and for that reason is said to be the support.

Because of this meaning, the Abhidharma masters say that in the formless realm, because there is no body, the same kind of life and so on rely on each other.

What are the destinies?
Where are they? How many are there?
A verse says:

The treatise says:

In the three realms, according to circumstances, there are five destinies. They are as their names indicate, namely, the hells, animals, hungry ghosts, humans, and celestials, which are called the five destinies.
Only the desire realm has all four destinies, and each of the three realms has a part of the celestial destiny.
In order to show that there are realms that are not included in the destinies, it is said in the three realms there are five destinies.
Good, defiled, indeterminate, sentient and nonsentient, and intermediate existence, etc., are all the nature of realms.
The substance of the destinies only includes the nondefiled and indeterminate, and sentient beings, but not intermediate existence.
As for the substance of the destinies only including the nondefiled and indeterminate, it is because only the nature of retribution is the substance of the destinies.
Consequently, this explains the destinies.
Because there is no nature of retribution in the sentient and nonsentient,
the substance of the destinies only includes the nondefiled and indeterminate.
This must be accepted as definitely true, as in the Sutra of the Seven Existences.

The scriptures speak of seven existences: the existence of hell beings, the existence of animals, the existence of hungry ghosts, the existence of celestials, the existence of humans, the existence of karma, and the existence of the intermediate state.
Among them, the existence of karma is the cause of the five destinies. In order to distinguish the destinies from their causes, it is separately mentioned.

This scripture aims to show that the essence of the destinies only includes the non-obscuring and indeterminate. Therefore, in order to distinguish them from their causes, the principle should be the same.

If wholesome and defiled dharmas were the essence of the destinies, the destinies would be confused, because many destinies of afflictions and karma could all be manifested and accomplished in the body of one destiny.
Karma is like the intermediate state, because they are both separately mentioned.

It is not like the defilement of views, because some sources say that views are afflictions. There is no source that says that karma is the essence of the destinies, so it cannot be used as an analogy.

Because the scriptures, treatises, and principles are the correct measure.

The destinies of hell beings, animals, hungry ghosts, humans, and gods, and the intermediate state of preparation.

If that is so, the formless realm should also not be a destiny, because one is born in the place of death.
It is not so. In the formless realm, one is born in the place of death, and does not go to another place.
Although in the intermediate state one is born in the place of death, one goes to another place, and therefore it is not the substance of a destiny.
The intermediate existence is the intermediate state between death and birth, because it definitely exists.
Between birth existence and death existence, there is no interval, so there is no prior existence. This is the error of calling it intermediate existence.
Or it is possible that it arises between the two births of different species, so it is called intermediate existence.
It cannot be said that it is called intermediate existence because it is between two destinies. The reason is not established because it is included in the category of destinies.
Among the realms and destinies explained above, there are seven abodes of consciousness in order.
